questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is true regarding renal vein thrombosis?

options.a: Right renal vein is more commonly involved
options.b: Most common cause in children is nephrotic syndrome
options.c: Investigation of choice is doppler ultrasound of renal vein
options.d: Most common cause in elderly is renal cell carcinoma

questions.explanation:
The most common cause of renal vein thrombosis in the elderly is renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The most common causes of renal vein thrombosis in different age groups are as follows: • Children - Dehydration, followed by sepsis • Adults - Nephrotic syndrome (most commonly membranous glomerulonephritis) • Elderly - Renal cell carcinoma The left renal vein is more commonly involved and 2/3rd of cases are bilateral. Doppler USG is 
used for screening but the investigation of choice is CT angiography.

questions.question: Question 3: What is the most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome globally?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) globally is Escherichia coli 
O157:H7. The causes of HUS are as follows: • Infections: Usually occur 5-10 days after diarrheal diseases due to bacterial exotoxins. • E.coli O157:H7 - Shiga-like toxin (verotoxin) • Shigella dysenteriae type I - Shiga toxin • Streptococcus pneumoniae • Autoimmunity • Complement activation (in atypical HUS)

questions.question:
Question 5: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset headache 
and photophobia. On examination, she is disoriented and febrile. The investigations and 
peripheral smear are given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding 
this disease?

options.a: It is caused by ADAMTS13 deficiency
options.b: 20% patients will have falsely positive RA factor
options.c: Arrhythmias are a frequent cause of death
options.d: Mainstay of treatment is blood transfusion

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) in a woman are 
suggestive of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Blood transfusion is not preferred in 
TTP as it can aggravate the condition. TTP is a type of thrombotic microangiopathy that occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies 
against the ADAMTS13 metalloprotease, which is responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor 
multimers. In the absence of this protein, vWF multimers aggregate and form thrombi. It presents 
with a classical pentad of clinical features: • Fever • Thrombocytopenia • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia • Renal failure • Neurological manifestations It is treated with plasmapheresis and rituximab.

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most■ common cause of clinically significant renal artery stenosis?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of clinically significant renal artery stenosis is atherosclerosis. Renal artery stenosis is a relatively common finding in older patients with chronic essential 
hypertension. However, it is considered clinically significant only when renovascular hypertension 
develops. It occurs in the case of: • > 70% stenosis in both renal arteries • > 50% stenosis with post stenotic dilatation The causes of renal artery stenosis are: • Atherosclerosis (most common) - common in older patients with cardiovascular risk factors • Fibromuscular dysplasia – more common in young, white females and is usually bilateral • Less common causes include: • Thromboemboli 775 
Sold by @itachibot • External compression by tumors • Systemic vasculitis • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome • Transplant renal artery stenosis • Infrarenal aortic aneurysms and dissections The investigation of choice for renal artery stenosis is renal angiography.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements is incorrect about fibromuscular dysplasia?

options.a: String of beads appearance on angiography
options.c: Most commonly affected peripheral artery is subclavian artery

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and the string of beads appearance on CT angiography is characteristic of 
fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common peripheral (limb) arteries affected are the iliac 
arteries. Fibromuscular dysplasia is a segmental, non-atheromatous, dysplastic type of angiopathy that 
predominantly affects females. The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia. It is one of the 
major causes of renovascular hypertension. The most common sites of involvement in decreasing 
order of frequency are as follows: • Renal arteries • Carotid arteries • Peripheral (limb) arteries - most commonly iliac arteries On angiography, a string of beads appearance is seen as shown below.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is unlikely in patients with atheroembolic kidney disease?
questions.explanation:
Atheroembolic kidney disease is associated with decreased complement levels. 776 
Sold by @itachibot Atheroembolic kidney disease is more frequent in males with a history of diabetes, hypertension, 
and ischemic heart disease. Most clinical atheroembolic events follow angiographic procedures, 
often of the coronary vessels. It is associated with aortic aneurysms and renal artery stenosis. Systemic embolic manifestations 
such as fever, abdominal pain, and weight loss are also present, although cutaneous 
manifestations are more common like livedo reticularis and localized toe gangrene. The lab findings include: • Rising serum creatinine • Transient eosinophilia • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate • Hypocomplementemia Definitive diagnosis depends on kidney biopsy which demonstrates microvessel occlusion with 
cholesterol crystals that leave a cleft in the vessel as shown below.

Question 9: A 50-year-old patient is being evaluated for uncontrolled hypertension despite being on 3 
antihypertensive drugs. He has a history of myocardial infarction which was managed with 
percutaneous intervention last month. On examination, an abdominal bruit is noted. Lab 
values indicate elevated serum urea and creatinine. Which of the following investigations is 
the gold standard test to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal artery stenosis. Renal intra-arterial angiography is the 
gold standard for diagnosis.In a patient with hypertension and increased creatinine, 
an ultrasound of the abdomen must be performed first to visualize the renal size and morphology 
to look for a unilateral shrunken kidney and thereby renal artery stenosis. Option A: MR angiography is less preferred as gadolinium contrast can lead to nephrogenic 
fibrosis, particularly in patients with reduced kidney function. Option C: CT scan with image reconstruction provides an excellent image but also carries a risk of 
contrast nephropathy. Option D: Renal arterial doppler ultrasound measures renal artery velocities and can predict 
hemodynamically important lesions. However, it is not the gold standard test. Duplex 777 
Sold by @itachibot ultrasonography is used as a screening investigation.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following drugs must be avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis?

options.a: Bulging of tricuspid valve into the right atrium
options.c: Venous filling of the right atrium
options.d: Emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle

questions.explanation:
ACE inhibitors must be avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis (RAS). In renal artery stenosis, blood flow to the kidney is reduced, thereby reducing blood flow to the 
afferent arterioles. Hence, constriction of efferent arterioles is needed to maintain hydrostatic 
pressure within the glomerulus in order to maintain GFR. ACEIs and ARBs inhibit efferent renal arteriolar vasoconstriction. In bilateral RAS, this causes a 
decline in the GFR within a few days of starting the drug. Note: Bilateral renal artery stenosis has been classically considered as an absolute 
contraindication to the use of ACE inhibitors. However, new studies show that they may be used 
in some cases with careful monitoring. 778 
Sold by @itachibot Diagnosis of cardiovascular disorders
